name: un-stressed face
indicator: Note features of face when not stressed. Eyes are relaxed and the lips should be full.

name: stressed face
indicator: A stressed face is tense and slightly contorted, eyebrows are knitted, and the forehead is furrowed.

name: turtle effect
indicator: The “turtle effect” (shoulders rise toward the ears) is often seen when people are humbled or suddenly lose confidence.

name: lean away
indicator: People lean away from each other subconsciously when they disagree or feel uncomfortable around each other

name: eye blocking
indicator: Eye blocking is a very powerful display of consternation, disbelief, or disagreement

name: cover the neck
indicator: Covering of the neck dimple pacifies insecurities, emotional discomfort, fear, or concerns in real time. Playing with a necklace often serves the same purpose

name: rub the forehead
indicator: Rubbing of the forehead is usually a good indicator that a person is struggling with something or is undergoing slight to severe discomfort.

name: neck touching
indicator: Neck touching takes place when there is emotional discomfort, doubt, or insecurity

name: cheek touching
indicator: Cheek or face touching is a way to pacify when nervous, irritated, or concerned.

name: puffed out cheeks
indicator: Exhaling with puffed out cheeks is a great way to release stress and to pacify. Notice how often people do this after a near mishap.

name: adjust the tie
indicator: Men adjust their ties to deal with insecurities or discomfort. It also covers the suprasternal notch.

name: massage the neck
indicator: Men tend to massage or stroke their necks to pacify distress. This area is rich with nerves, including the vagus nerve, which when massaged will slow down the heart rate.

name: cover the neck
indicator: Men typically cover their necks more robustly than women as a way to deal with discomfort or insecurity.

name: touch the neck
indicator: Even a brief touch of the neck will serve to assuage anxiety or discomfort. Neck touching or massaging is a powerful and universal stress reliever and pacifier.

name: cleanse palms
indicator: When stressed or nervous, people will “cleanse” their palms on their laps in order to pacify themselves. Often missed under tables, it is a very accurate indicator of discomfort or anxiety

name: ventilate neck area
indicator: Ventilating of the neck area relieves stress and emotional discomfort. Rodney Dangerfield, the comedian, was famous for doing this when he wasn’t getting any “respect.”

name: one foot turn away
indicator: Where one foot points and turns away during a conversation, this is a sign the person has to leave, precisely in that direction. This is an intention cue.

name: clasping of the knees
indicator: Clasping of the knees and shifting of weight on the feet is an intention cue that the person wants to get up and leave.

name: toe point upward
indicator: When the toes point upward as in this photograph, it usually means the person is in a good mood or is thinking or hearing something positive.

name: starter's position
indicator: When feet shift from flat footed to the “starter’s position,” this is an intention cue that the person wants to go.

name: cross legs
indicator: We normally cross our legs when we feel comfortable. The sudden presence of someone we don’t like will cause us to uncross our legs.

name: both cross legs
indicator: When two people are talking and both have crossed their legs, this is an indication that they are very comfortable around each other

name: knee as a barrier
indicator: In this photo the man has placed his right leg in such a way that the knee acts as a barrier between himself and the woman.

name: knee barrier removed
indicator: In this photo the man has positioned his leg so that the knee is further away, removing barriers between himself and the woman.

name: feet pointed away
indicator: When a person talks to you with feet pointed away, it is a good indication this person wants to be elsewhere. Watch for people who make formal declarations in this position, as this is a form of distancing.

name: foot sudden kick
indicator: When a foot suddenly begins to kick, it is usually a good indicator of discomfort. You see this with people being interviewed, as soon as a question is asked they do not like.

name: interlock of legs
indicator: A sudden interlocking of the legs may suggest discomfort or insecurity. When people are comfortable, they tend to unlock their ankles.

name: lock of ankles
indicator: The sudden locking of ankles around the legs of a chair is part of the freeze response and is indicative of discomfort, anxiety, or concern.

name: lean toward
indicator: People lean toward each other when there is high comfort and agreement. This mirroring or isopraxis starts when we are babies.

name: lean away
indicator: We lean away from things and people we don’t like, even from colleagues when they say things with which we don’t agree.

name: cross of arms
indicator: A sudden crossing of the arms during a conversation could indicate discomfort.

name: cross arms comfortably
indicator: In public, many of us comfortably cross our arms while waiting or listening to a speaker. Around the house we rarely sit this way unless something is bothering us, like waiting for a late ride.

name: cross arms tightly
indicator: Crossed arms with hands tightly gripping the arms is definitely an indication of discomfort.

name: splay out
indicator: Splaying out is a territorial display, which is OK in your own home but not in the work place, especially during a job interview.

name: partial shoulder shrug
indicator: Partial shoulder shrugs indicate lack of commitment or insecurity

name: shoulder shrug
indicator: We use shoulder shrugs to indicate lack of knowledge or doubt. Look for both shoulders to rise; when only one side rises, the message is dubious.

name: turtle effect
indicator: Shoulders rising toward the ears causes the “turtle effect”; weakness, insecurity, and negative emotions are the message. Think of losing athletes walking back to the locker room.

name: regal stance
indicator: Sometimes called the “regal stance,” arms behind the back mean “don’t draw near.” You see royalty using this behavior to keep people at a distance.

name: arms akimbo
indicator: Arms akimbo is a powerful territorial display that can be used to establish dominance or to communicate that there are “issues.”

name: woman arms akimbo
indicator: Women tend to use arms akimbo less than men. Note the position of the thumbs in this photograph.

name: arms akimbo thumb forward
indicator: In this photo the arms are akimbo, but note that the thumbs are forward. This is a more inquisitive, less authoritarian position than in the previous photo, where the thumbs are back in the “there are issues” position.

name: interlaced hands behind the head
indicator: Interlaced hands behind the head are indicative of comfort and dominance. Usually the senior person at a meeting will pose or “hood” this way

name: fingertips planted spread apart on a surface
indicator: Fingertips planted spread apart on a surface are a significant territorial display of confidence and authority

name: arms spread out
indicator: Arms spread out over chairs tell the world you are feeling confident and comfortable.

name: finger pointing
indicator: Perhaps one of the most offensive gestures we possess is finger pointing. It has negative connotations around the globe.

name: self preening
indicator: Self-preening is acceptable, but not when others are talking to you. This is a sign of dismissiveness.

name: nail biting
indicator: Nail-biting is generally perceived as a sign of insecurity or nervousness.

name: steepling of hands
indicator: Steepling of hands, fingertip to fingertip, is one of the most powerful displays of confidence we possess.

name: hand wringing
indicator: Hand-wringing is a universal way of showing we are stressed or concerned.

name: thumb stick out of pocket
indicator: Often seen with high-status individuals, the thumb sticking out of the pocket is a high-confidence display.

name: thumbs up
indicator: Thumbs up is usually a good indication of positive thoughts. This can be very fluid during a conversation.

name: thumbs disappear
indicator: The thumbs can suddenly disappear, as in this photo, when there is less emphasis or emotions turn negative.

name: thumbs in the pocket
indicator: Thumbs in the pocket indicate low status and confidence. People in authority should avoid this display because it sends the wrong message.

name: thumbs in the pocket
indicator: Often used as a sign of insecurity or social discomfort, thumbs in the pocket transmit this message readily and thus should be avoided.

name: frame the genitals
indicator: Using the hands to frame the genitals is often seen with young males and females during the courtship years. It is a dominance display

name: stroke fingers across the palm
indicator: We often pacify anxiety or nervousness by stroking our fingers across the palm or rubbing our hands together.

name: fingers interlace to rub up and down
indicator: When the fingers interlace to rub up and down, as in this photo, the brain is asking for extra hand contact to pacify more serious concerns or anxiety

name: squint
indicator: Squinting, furrowing of the forehead, and facial contortions are indicative of distress or discomfort.

name: head tilt
indicator: Head tilt says in a powerful way, “I am comfortable, I am receptive, I am friendly.” It is very difficult to do this around people we don’t like.

name: pupils dilation and constriction
indicator: In this diagram you can see pupil dilation and constriction. From birth we find comfort in dilated pupils, especially those with whom we are emotionally attached.

name: squint
indicator: We squint to block out light or objectionable things. We squint when we are angry or even when we hear voices, sounds, or music we don’t like.

name: brief squint
indicator: Squinting can be very brief—1⁄8 of second—but in real time may reflect a negative thought or emotion.

name: eye blocking
indicator: Eye blocking with the hands is an effective way of saying, “I don’t like what I just heard, saw, or learned.”

name: touch of eyes
indicator: A brief touch of the eyes during a conversation may give you a clue to a person’s negative perception of what is being discussed.

name: delay in opening of eyelids
indicator: A delay in opening of the eyelids upon hearing information or a lengthy closure is indicative of negative emotions or displeasure.

name: eyelids compress
indicator: Where the lids compress tightly as in this photo, the person is trying to block out totally some negative news or event.

name: relaxed eyes
indicator: When we are content, our eyes are relaxed and show little tension.

name: arched eyeborws
indicator: Here the eyebrows are arched slightly, defying gravity, a sure sign of positive feelings.

name: flashbulb eyes
indicator: Flashbulb eyes can be seen when we are excited to see someone or are full of positive emotions we just can’t hold back.

name: look askance
indicator: We look askance at people when we are distrustful or unconvinced, as in this photo.

name: real smile
indicator: A real smile forces the corners of the mouth up toward the eyes.

name: polite smile
indicator: This is a fake or “polite smile”: the corners of the mouth move toward the ears and there is little emotion in the eyes.

name: lips disappear
indicator: When the lips disappear, there is usually stress or anxiety driving this behavior.

name: lips full
indicator: Note that when the lips are full, usually the person is content.

name: lips tighten
indicator: When there is stress, the lips will begin to disappear and tighten.

name: lips compression
indicator: Lip compression, reflecting stress or anxiety, may progress to the point where the lips disappear, as in this photo.

name: corner of mouth turn down
indicator: When the lips disappear and the corners of the mouth turn down, emotions and confidence are at a low point, while anxiety, stress, and concerns are running high.

name: purse lips
indicator: We purse our lips or pucker them when we are in disagreement with something or someone, or we are thinking of a possible alternative.

name: sneer fleetlingly
indicator: A sneer fleetingly signifies disrespect or disdain. It says “I care little for you or your thoughts.”

name: lip licking
indicator: Lip licking is a pacifying behavior that tends to soothe and calm us down. You see it in class just before a test.

name: tongue jutting
indicator: Tongue jutting is seen when people get caught doing something they shouldn’t, they screw up, or they are getting away with something. It is very brief.

name: furrowed forehead
indicator: A furrowed forehead is an easy way to assess for discomfort or anxiety. When we are happy and content, you hardly see this behavior.

name: crinkle nose
indicator: A furrowed forehead is an easy way to assess for discomfort or anxiety. When we are happy and content, you hardly see this behavior.

name: chin tuck in
indicator: When confidence is low or we are concerned for ourselves, the chin will tuck in, forcing the nose down.

name: chin come out
indicator: When we feel positive, the chin comes out and the nose is high: both signs of comfort and confidence.

name: isopraxis
indicator: Here is an example of isopraxis: Both people are mirroring each other and leaning toward each other, showing signs of high comfort.

name: flash frozen
indicator: Sitting for long periods in a chair, as though flash frozen in an ejector seat, is evidence of high stress and discomfort.

name: palms up
indicator: The palms-up or “rogatory” position usually indicates the person wants to be believed or wants to be accepted. It is not a dominant, confident display

name: palms down
indicator: Statements made palm down are more emphatic and more confident than statements made with hands palm up in the rogatory position.
